This report was prepared by H. Yamaguchi.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Republic of the Maldives has requested Asian Development Bank (ADB) technical 
assistance (TA) to conduct a feasibility study of improving domestic maritime transport for ADB 
financing.1 An ADB Mission visited the Maldives in July 2004 to undertake fact-finding for the TA 
and  reached  an  understanding  with  the  Government  on  the  goal,  purpose,  scope, 
implementation arrangements, and terms of reference of the TA. The TA is included in Country 
Strategy and Program Update, 2004–2006. The preliminary project framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The Maldives consists of about 1,190 islands, grouped into 20 administrative atolls. 
Each atoll is a coral reef surrounding a lagoon. Malé is the capital city and is also designated as 
one of the administrative atolls. Almost all land masses are very small, averaging only 16 
hectares. Over 80% of the land mass is less than 1 meter above mean sea level, exposing the 
population to tidal waves, storms, and the risk of an increase in the sea level resulting from 
global warming. The population of 270,000 is scattered among 200 inhabited islands. A quarter 
of the population reside on Malé. The Maldives has no known mineral resources and scant 
arable land. However, due to well-performing tourism and fisheries industries dominating the 
economy — the two accounting for nearly 40% of gross domestic product (GDP)  — the 
economy has achieved high growth of 7.4% annually since 1991, and per capita GDP increased 
from $1,711 in 1997 to $2,261 in 2003.2 
 
3.  Despite the high level of economic growth in recent years, a large segment of the 
Maldives’ population subsists on very low incomes and are considered poor. The Vulnerability 
and Poverty Assessment3 reports that, as of 1998, 43% of the population subsists on a per 
capita income of Rf15 ($1.30) per day or less, and almost 90% of them reside in the atolls. 
Income disparities were in the order of 2:1, and access to social and physical infrastructure and 
services was even worse, averaging 4:1. Isolation is an important element of human poverty in 
many atolls (Appendix 2). Further, limited transportation opportunities add to remoteness and 
isolation. One third of the atoll population report that opportunities to travel to Malé are limited to 
2–3 sailings per week. Access problems were reported by half of the atoll population due to 
problems with harbors, absence of a jetty, or penetrating reefs. 
 
4.  In its Sixth National Development Plan (2001–2005), the Government emphasizes the 
importance of regionally balanced development through the focus islands in five regional growth 
centers in the north, south, north-central, central, and south-central atolls, for balanced provision 
of economic and social services. Consistent with this national development  objective, ADB 
financed the first Regional Development Project  (RDP I)4 to facilitate equitable  development 
including the provision of basic infrastructure and capacity building. The Sea Transport Study5

5.  Domestic transport of freight and passengers is predominantly by sea. As there are no 
significant  regional  centers  in  the  Maldives  apart  from  Gan  Island  in  the  south,  domestic 
maritime freight and passenger traffic is dominated by movements directly between Malé and 
individual small island communities. In this regard, Malé-to-outer islands traffic is almost entirely 
import cargo transshipped at Malé Port. Heavy congestion prevails at the inter-atoll harbor in 
Malé. Regular maritime transport services between Malé and the outer islands, and within and 
between the outer atolls, are few and infrequent. Interisland shipping services are operated 
entirely by the private sector, while the Government provides essential infrastructure such as 
ports and deepened harbors, and regulatory functions like maritime safety.  
 
6.  The extent of transport facilities varies considerably from island to island. Some islands 
have man-made harbors, while others have natural harbors, lagoons, and jetties of different 
lengths and construction. In addition, there are islands that have neither natural harbors nor 
even jetties for unloading and access to the islands. A total of 100 islands in the country still 
have  no  harbors.  Most  of  the  existing  man-made  harbors  do  not  meet  the  minimum 
requirements  of  the  Ministry  of  Atoll  Development  (MOAD).  Some  major  harbors  need 
substantial rehabilitation due to deterioration, which has caused bottlenecks to the movement of 
people and goods. Restricted movement has hampered efforts to regional development. 
 
7.  Currently,  government  interventions  in  private  operations  in  the  domestic  maritime 
transport subsector are minimal. One of the limited government interventions is user charges in 
Malé harbor.  However, the regulations are not enforced at Northern Inter-Atoll Harbor. As a 
result, the harbor is congested and lacks funding for maintenance. No user charges are levied 
on users of transport infrastructure in outer islands where costs of minor maintenance are 
collected from vessel owners when necessary and costs of major maintenance are requested 
from the Government. Though there is a harbor maintenance program under  MOAD, its very 
limited budget6 results in the deterioration of harbors, jetties, and other facilities (para. 6). The 
limited Government support to private operators in terms of finance, physical infrastructure, and 
institutional arrangement results in few regular and frequent services, and compromises the 
safety and convenience of the passengers. 
 
8.  The  Ministry  of  Transport  and  Civil  Aviation  (MTCA)  is  responsible  for  overall 
development of maritime transport networks. The Ministry of Construction and Public Works 
(MCPW) is responsible for constructing maritime infrastructure such as harbors and jetties in 
Malé and islands in the vicinity of Malé. For the outer atolls, MOAD identifies islands in need of 
harbor development and submits its requirements and recommendations to the Ministry of 
Planning and National Development (MPND), which then decides on where money provided by 
the Ministry of Finance and Treasury (MOFT) is to be invested. Once harbors and jetties have 
been built, ongoing maintenance of infrastructure then falls under the responsibility of the 
various island offices; if major costs are involved, central Government funding may be made 
available. Most line ministries have limited absorptive capacity due to the scarcity of skilled and 
experienced staff. 
 
9.  Since 1979, ADB has provided the Maldives with four loan projects in the transport 
sector. They include an attempt to initiate a scheduled interisland transport service and support

3 
to improve the operations of Malé Port. Except for the Interisland Transport Project,7 approved 
by ADB in 1981, ADB’s past assistance in the transport sector proved successful in extending 
the physical capacity of Malé Port and upgrading its institutional capacity. Important lessons 
learned from the Interisland Transport Project for improving domestic maritime transport in the 
country  include  the  following:  (i)  transport  is  only  one  factor  in  economic  and  social 
development; by itself, it cannot promote development; (ii) the project needs to be built on the 
existing formal and informal transport activities in terms of routes and operation, and any 
attempts by the Government to intervene in private sector provision of transport services should 
be considered with extreme caution; (iii) island-specific shoreline, e.g., limited accessibility to 
large vessels due to shallowness, and demand characteristics, need to be well taken  into 
account; and (iv) an appropriate regulatory and pricing framework of interisland transport needs 
to be set up. 
 
10.  The  ADB-financed  transport  master  plan8 currently  being  finalized  will  identify  the 
general transport policies, strategies, legal and regulatory framework, investment programs, and 
activities necessary for ensuring a nationwide integrated transport network. Among investment 
programs proposed under the draft transport master plan, the Government has decided that the 
inter- and intra-atoll maritime transport is the most immediate priority. The draft transport master 
plan  also  has  recommendations  for  implementing  policies  in  the  transport  sector. 
Recommendations pertinent to domestic maritime transport are (i) medical and food emergency 
issues; (ii) operation and maintenance (O&M) scheme for harbors and facilities through a cost 
recovery mechanism with consistent user charges; (iii) government support or deregulation to 
assist  private  sector  operators  in  providing  reliable  services;  and  (iv)  cross-cutting  issues 
including environment, capacity building, and maritime safety.  
 
11.  Lack of reliable services and inadequate infrastructure are major obstacles to safe and 
efficient domestic maritime transport. The regularity, frequency, and cost of transport services 
have a significant impact on the social and economic development of the islands. Having an 
integrated,  efficient  transport  network  that  systematically  links  Malé,  the  regional  centers 
currently  under  development,  and  the  surrounding  atolls  will  be  key  to  ensuring  that 
socioeconomic growth in the Maldives is distributed equitably. Assistance is therefore required 
to improve the domestic maritime transport system to provide safer, more efficient and more 
accessible  services.  Such  assistance  will  support  the  development  of  various  sectors  in 
fostering  regionally  balanced  growth  and  take  into  account  the  lessons  learned  and  the 
conceptual framework of the transport master plan. ADB's operational strategy for the Maldives 
is consistent with these objectives. The likely improvements to the maritime transport system 
may include (i) improving harbors and facilities, with O&M programming, in Malé and selected 
islands; (ii) improving vessels to provide appropriate space for passengers; (iii) facilitating 
information and communication about planned travel, including possible scheduled services; 
and (iv) strengthening maritime safety.     
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
12.  The safe and efficient  domestic  maritime  transport  system  will  contribute  to  poverty

4 
reduction, regionally balanced economic growth, and national integration. The purpose of the 
TA is to identify ways to improve maritime transport, and develop a project for possible ADB 
financing, including (i) required facilities for maritime transport; and (ii) technical, institutional, 
and policy solutions for improving the safety, efficiency, and accessibility of the existing maritime 
transport system. The TA will also identify a sustainable and effective delivery mechanism for 
maintaining the proposed facilities; technical, organizational, institutional, and human resources 
improvements for efficient transport services; and cost recovery or subsidy mechanisms that will 
allow effective and consistent O&M  of facilities and vessels. The TA will support a feasibility 
study of the project from the engineering, economic, social, and environmental points of view in 
accordance with ADB policies, operational procedures, and guidelines. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  Existing ocean routes and detailed needs will initially be identified and assessed based 
on existing studies such as the Sea Transport Study (2000), Transport Master Plan (2004), and 
relevant development policies and strategies; and an additional survey to supplement existing 
studies. On the basis of the assessment, the core routes to  connect focal islands or where 
safety  and  economic  inefficiency  problems  occur  will  be  identified.  After  core  routes  are 
identified, ways to improve the transport service will be determined based on traffic demand 
forecast and other requirements. Then, preliminary designs and cost estimates for the proposed 
improvements, including physical facilities and vessels, and schemes for service provision, will 
be prepared. Annual and regular O&M programs for the next 10 years will be prepared. A 
sustainable management mechanism for delivering the proposed facilities and services will also 
be prepared. A cost recovery mechanism with appropriate user charges will be established to 
provide for the proposed improvements, taking into account users' willingness to pay. Economic, 
social, and environmental assessment will be conducted in accordance with ADB's and the 
Government's  policies,  guidelines,  and  procedural  requirements.  Finally,  implementation 
arrangements  and  institutional  requirements  will  be  proposed  for  project  execution  and 
maintenance, taking into account difficulties due to geographic and socioeconomic conditions. 
The feasibility study will be prepared in a format suitable for use in further processing by ADB 
for possible loan financing. 
 
14.  Consultation  meetings  involving  public  and  private  sector  entities,  i.e.,  concerned 
ministries, transport service providers, transport service users, especially local communities in 
focal islands, will be held at the early stage to appropriately design the project, incorporating 
existing transport systems. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $590,000 equivalent, comprising $380,000 in 
foreign  exchange,  and  $210,000  equivalent  in  local  currency.  ADB  will  provide  $500,000 
equivalent, covering the entire foreign exchange cost and a portion of the local currency cost of 
$120,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis from ADB’s TA funding program. 
The Government will finance the remaining $90,000 equivalent of the local currency cost 
through in-kind contributions of the Executing Agency and Implementing Agency. The detailed 
cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 3. 
 
16.  The Government has been advised that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to 
finance any ensuing project.

5 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  MOFT will be the Executing Agency and MTCA will be the Implementing Agency for the 
TA. MTCA will nominate a core group of counterpart staff, headed by a TA director, to work 
closely with the consultants for day-to-day implementation and to report the progress of the TA 
to ADB. A steering committee chaired by the TA director and comprising representatives from 
stakeholder ministries such as MOFT, MPND, MTCA, MOAD and MCPW will be established 
before the consultants are fielded to give them overall guidance. 
 
18.  The TA will be implemented over 6 months, starting in January 2005 and ending in July 
2005. Approval of advance action for recruiting consultants was approved in August 2004. 
 
19.  A multidisciplinary team of consultants will provide a total input of 45 person-months of 
consulting  services:  15  international  and  30  domestic.  Both  international  and  domestic 
consultants will have expertise in (i) transport planning and economics (maritime), (ii) maritime 
or coastal engineering, (iii) financial analysis in maritime transport, (iv) resettlement with social 
analysis, and (v) maritime environmental assessment. For maritime safety, domestic inputs will 
be provided for a public awareness program. The team of consultants, from an international 
consulting firm in association with domestic consultants, will be selected and engaged by ADB 
using ADB’s quality- and cost-based selection procedures and in accordance with its Guidelines 
on  the  Use  of  Consultants  (using  the  simplified  technical  proposal  procedure)  and  other 
arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for  engaging  domestic  consultants.  Equipment  will  be 
procured in accordance with ADB’s  Guidelines for Procurement  under the direct purchase 
procedure. Appendix 4 gives the outline terms of reference for the consultants. 
 
20.  The consultants will submit (i) an inception report within 1 month, (ii) an interim report 
within 3 months, and (iii) a draft final report within 5 months of the start of the feasibility study. In 
addition, the consultants will submit a final report within 1 month of receipt of comments on the 
draft final report after due consideration of comments made by the Government and ADB. The 
inception report will highlight the progress made, initial findings with candidate project elements, 
and any recommendations and proposed changes to the work program. The interim report will 
include preliminary study results for the proposed project. Necessary inputs and assistance will 
be provided to assist the ADB loan processing fact-finding mission. The draft final report will 
include final study results for the project, including reports on safeguard issues to be used in 
loan preparation. During TA implementation, meetings between the steering committee and 
consultants will be held monthly in Malé or as needed, to review and discuss TA progress. The 
monthly progress report will be sent to the Government and ADB. A tripartite meeting to discuss 
the inception, interim, and draft final reports, respectively, will be held in Malé within 1 month of 
issuance of each report. 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the Maldives for preparing the Domestic Maritime Transport Project, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in the Maldives: 
 
Isolation is an important element of human poverty in many atolls of the Maldives. Limited transportation opportunities 
add to remoteness and isolation. Access problems were mainly due to problems with harbors, absence of a jetty, or 
problems of penetrating reefs. In addition, maritime transport services provided between Malé and outer islands, and 
within and between outer atolls are few and infrequent. The project will help to reduce poverty by improving inter- and 
intra-atoll maritime transport in the Maldives. It will increase transportation opportunities and accessibility, which will 
enable the poor to reach general food and merchandise provisions, as well as health, education, and social services 
and supplies. 
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                        Proposed Poverty Classification:1 Poverty Intervention  
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
 
A poverty and social analysis will be carried out to identify the socio-economic profile of the population in the project 
area, expected benefits and constraints, and ability of the poor and vulnerable groups to benefit from the project. The 
project will also build on the findings of poverty and vulnerability assessment carried out by the Government through 
United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) support in 1999.

Is there a stakeholder analysis?    Yes     No  
The project design will be developed through stakeholder consultations. 
 
Is there a participation strategy?     Yes                   No 
The TA will include a design of a participation strategy to apply before and during the construction and operation and 
maintenance period. 
 
D.  Gender Development 
  
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
 
Maldivian women are recognized among the most emancipated in South Asia and in the Islamic world. No institutional 
discrimination along gender lines exists in access to education, health services, and jobs in the public sector. Due to 
the strong migration (as a result of the economic situation) of men to Malé, the population of these islands is 
composed of mostly women and children. Women’s groups are being established and are gaining momentum. Project 
design will include measures so that women’s groups can be actively engaged in developing the project to ensure that 
their needs are addressed.

10  Appendix 4 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTING SERVICES  
 
A.  Feasibility Study 
 
1.  The Project will develop an efficient inter- and intra-atoll maritime transport network 
based on the existing network or operation by (i) improving harbors and facilities in  Malé and 
selected islands; and (ii) implementing schemes for service operators, including individual 
private operators, to provide more reliable and accessible services. The feasibility study will 
prepare a project that will be processed in 2005 for possible Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
financing, including (i) required facilities for maritime transport; and (ii) technical, institutional, 
and policy solutions for improving the safety, efficiency, and accessibility of the existing maritime 
transport system. 
 
2.  The team leader will work in the Maldives for the duration of the assignment, and will 
coordinate the preparation of all documentation required by ADB guidelines and assist the ADB 
project officer in developing the report and recommendation of the president document for the 
ensuing  loan,  including  (i)  a  detailed  project  logical  framework;  (ii)  project  performance 
monitoring and evaluation arrangements, including baseline data; and (iii) an assessment of the 
detailed procurement and implementation arrangements. The team leader will be accountable 
for the quality and timeliness of all deliverables, and will ensure that all components are clearly 
and concisely documented to the full satisfaction of the ADB and Government project teams. 
The team leader will also ensure that the proposed investment that will be prepared through the 
feasibility component is complete, cohesive, economically and financially viable, and in full 
compliance  with  all  pertinent  ADB  and  Government  policies  and  guidelines.  The detailed 
consultants' work will include, but will not necessarily be limited to, the following tasks: 
 
1.  Transport Planner and Economist (Maritime) 
3.  The specialist will carry out these tasks: 
 
(i)  Review the transport master plan study and other relevant studies such as the 
Sea  Transport  Study  (STS)  in  2000  under  the  first  Regional  Development 
Project;  update  investment  proposals,  policies,  and  plans  in  the  maritime 
transport subsector; review the technical solutions and specifications, proposed 
locations, and land acquisition issues. 
(ii)  Identify existing ocean routes (formal and informal) and assess needs based on 
existing studies and additional surveys. For the assessment, identify (a) focal 
islands; (b) the impact of transportation and freight prices on remote island 
communities, and of maritime infrastructure and services on poverty; (c) the 
safety concerns of all communities; and (d) problems inherent in the present 
systems of passenger and cargo maritime transport, including those experienced 
by users and operators. 
(iii)  Determine core routes connecting focal islands or where safety and economic 
inefficiency problems occur, their usage and growth patterns, and alternative 
more reliable networks; and describe the proposed alternative technical solution 
and related resource requirements, in line with the transport master plan and 
additional assessment conducted in item (ii).  
(iv)  Propose project elements for a safe and efficient maritime transport network or 
system whereby operators can arrive safely at their destinations, and possible 
protected locations that facilitate the exchange of passengers and cargo to and

from small craft, dhonis,1 and vessels, and larger vessels delivering cargo; and 
users can access the transport service more conveniently and efficiently. This 
may include introducing Global Positioning System (GPS) for vessel positioning 
and schedule information and a scheme that offers incentives for operators to 
provide scheduled and reliable services. Build the proposed transport network or 
system on the existing system of transport operation as discussed in the STS. 
Also assess vessel design for better utilization, including possible design of 
passenger space in cargo vessels.  
(v)  Review the demand for the core network and assess traffic movements and 
needs of communities by obtaining data on the patterns of small craft traffic, 
commerce, microtrading, and delivery of social and health services. Assess the 
use of new technologies, know-how, and best practices for improving service 
delivery. 
(vi)  Conduct a traffic survey, supplementing existing studies — the transport master 
plan study and STS  — to analyze and forecast the demand (patterns and 
volumes) on the core routes. Also collect data from operators to examine the 
reasons for the current limitations of their services. 
(vii)  Assess the economic and financial viability of the Project in accordance with 
ADB's  Guidelines  for  the  Economic  Analysis  of  Projects,  by  evaluating 
environmental  and  social  costs  and  benefits  over  the  intended  life  of  the 
investment, preparing the financial and economic net present values of the 
proposals and other feasibility indicators, sensitivity tests for major parameters 
such as costs, demand, and benefits. Calculate financial and economic values 
for all parameters. 
(viii)  Estimate the expected distribution of net benefits among freight transport users, 
passenger  transport  users,  vessel  owners,  labor,  the  Government,  and  the 
economy in general; and conduct poverty impact assessment in accordance with 
ADB's Handbook for Integrating Poverty Impact Assessment in the Economic 
Analysis of Projects.  
(ix)  Develop  an  action  plan  to  address  policy,  institutional,  management, 
maintenance, and sustainable operation issues of the proposed facilities and 
transport  services,  including  a  cost  recovery  mechanism  and  appropriate 
allocation of functions between the public and the private sector. 
(x)  Conduct a quantitative risk analysis in accordance with ADB’s  Handbook for 
Integrating Risk Analysis in the Economic Analysis of Projects. 
 
2.  Maritime or Coastal Engineer 
 
4.  The tasks of the specialist are as follows: 
 
(i)  Survey  current  loading  and  unloading  practices  in  the  project  islands,  and 
propose safe and efficient loading and unloading facilities and systems, taking 
into  account  island-specific  characteristics  of  geography,  community  and 
services. Ensure that the technical solution will be cost-effective in terms of the 
life cycle cost and have minimum environmental impacts.  
(ii)  Survey the possible safe havens along the foreshore, and determine locations of 
proposed wharves, jetties, or pontoon sites, and shoal areas in the approaches 
to the safe havens where navigation aids are needed. Propose facilities to suit 
each location. 
                                                 
1  Traditional Maldivian seagoing boats for all purposes.

12  Appendix 4 
(iii)  Investigate the costs of locally available and imported materials for construction 
purposes;  estimate  costs  of  constructing,  installing,  and  maintaining  the 
proposed  facilities;  and  disaggregate  cost  estimates  into  foreign  and  local 
components, taxes and customs duties, equipment depreciation, spare parts, 
materials, labor, and overhead, etc. as well as by general items, civil works, 
electric works, installation, and equipment. 
(iv)  Prepare technical specifications and cost estimates including land acquisition 
and  resettlement  (if  any),  civil  works,  equipment  and  consulting  services 
required, by reviewing landing facilities, navigation aids, programs to improve the 
safety  of  operating  small  craft,  shipping  services,  and  programs  to  reduce 
poverty; and establish the contract packages considering the contract amount 
and the competition level of domestic contractors. 
(v)  Prepare  management  and  administration  arrangements  for  effective  project 
implementation including a project management unit (PMU); schedules; roles 
and tasks for agencies, communities, and persons involved; action programs for 
establishing project implementation resources including counterpart resources; 
and assess the capacity of the Ministry of Transport and Civil Aviation (MTCA) 
and other relevant authorities for management and contract administration for the 
investment program.  
(vi)  Identify  appropriate  implementation  arrangements  for  the  proposed  program, 
including a PMU and the steering committee, and prepare for, among other 
things, financial management of the project and coordination between MTCA, 
Ministry of Atoll Development (MOAD), and Ministry of Finance and Treasury 
(MOFT), and other relevant authorities. 
(vii)  Analyze, in detail, institutional options for improving remote and small craft safety 
— including dissemination of information, registry and reporting, early warning, 
search-and-rescue operations — considering economic efficiency, sustainability, 
financial and technical viability, and legal implications. 
(viii)  Prepare performance indicators for the project and improvement of maritime 
transport safety, and assign benchmark and target values to be achieved. 
(ix)  Recommend  appropriate  training  programs  to  enhance  the  improvement  of 
maritime transport safety, project implementation, management of the proposed 
maintenance  program,  and  sustainability  of  the  proposed  long-term 
institutionalization of the proposals; and develop a formal staff training program 
based on the needs and the performance requirements, exploring opportunities 
with any natural partners and organizations. 
(x)  Prepare a public awareness program for educating the public on the safety of 
maritime  transport,  especially  with  inputs  from  the  domestic  communication 
specialist. 
 
3.  Financial Analyst in Maritime Transport 
 
5.  The specialist will undertake these tasks: 
 
(i)  Carry out willingness-to-pay surveys, collect and analyze data on market fares, 
and compare these in light of the expansion of economic and financial service- 
supply prices; assess the existing payment or fare system for transport services, 
and propose systems for efficient use of harbors and vessels in line with ADB’s 
Economic Research Department Technical Notes No. 9 (Setting User Charges 
for Public Services: Policies and Practice at ADB) and No. 10 (Beyond Cost 
Recovery: Setting User Charges for Financial, Economic, and Social Goals).

Appendix 4  13 
(ii)  Identify all recurrent cost implications of the shipping and maritime transport 
infrastructure  proposals,  operating  and  maintaining  the  infrastructure, 
government  and  community  staffing,  enforcing  small-craft  registration  and 
policing; and assess the government's absorptive capacity for the new functions. 
(iii)  Identify cost recovery possibilities, and assess the capability and willingness of 
the Government to subsidize services to and from low-volume destinations in line 
with ADB's Criteria for Subsidies. Participate in ADB-led policy dialogue on the 
issue of possible subsidies based on interim and final findings. 
(iv)  Identify  an  appropriate  10-year  recurrent  maintenance  program,  including  a 
recommendation for funding the maintenance of the proposed facilities. 
(v)  Prepare  delivery  mechanisms  for  the  maintenance  program  addressing  the 
organizational,  technical,  financial,  and  human  resources  aspects  and 
coordination. Involve MTCA and other relevant agencies, including institutional 
changes  required  (e.g.,  re-engineering  Maldives  Ports  Authority  [MPA], 
expanding its roles to the interisland harbor, etc.), as appropriate. 
 
4.  Resettlement and Social Analyst 
 
6.  The specific tasks of the specialist are as follows: 
 
(i)  Conduct an initial poverty and social impact assessment including assessment of 
possible  land  acquisition  or  relocation  impacts.  Apply  relevant  screening 
checklists provided by ADB. 
(ii)  Conduct a poverty and social assessment in accordance with ADBs Handbook 
for  Poverty  and  Social  Analysis  and  Guidelines  for  Incorporation  of  Social 
Dimensions  in  Bank  Operations.  The  analysis,  in  full  consultation  with 
stakeholders,  will  (a)  identify  the  users  and  project  beneficiaries,  their 
socioeconomic profiles, needs and demands, livelihood, income, education, use 
of  maritime  transport,  and  expenses  incurred;  (b)  identify  alternative 
transportation  and  facilities;  (c)  assess  the  needs  of  the  client  groups  for 
navigation aids in relation to their other needs (e.g., hospitals, schools, livelihood 
opportunities, etc.); (d) assess the activities of the client group that complement 
the project proposal (e.g., fishing, access issues) and problems with the current 
maritime transportation conditions; (e) determine the preferred improvements, 
and the willingness of the user subgroups to pay the relevant fees as suggested 
under the cost recovery proposal; (f) identify institutional mechanisms to target 
poor beneficiaries; and (g) incorporate specific features or measures into the 
proposed project design to maximize poverty reduction through consultative and 
participatory approaches. 
(iii)  Assess  the  impacts  of  relocation  and  resettlement,  if  any,  on  the  affected 
population. Prepare involuntary resettlement and ethnic minority development 
plans according to ADB’s  Handbook on Involuntary Resettlement  and ADB's 
Policy on Indigenous People. 
(iv)  Formulate a participation strategy for preparing and implementing the Project. 
With the participation of stakeholders, groups at risk with respect to the Project, 
identify and analyze the reasons for their vulnerability, including their exposure to 
risks as described in ADB’s Handbook for Poverty and Social Analysis. 
(v)  In  coordination  with  the  economic  analysis,  design  a  time-bound  benefit 
monitoring and evaluation program, including monitoring indicators and baseline 
data, for assessing the benefits of the Project to local communities. The program 
should address not only economic benefits but also other social benefits.

14  Appendix 4 
5.  Environmental Specialist (Maritime) 
 
7.  The specialist will carry out these tasks: 
 
(i)  Gather and review all available environmental studies and data related to the 
project area; conduct preliminary environmental impact assessment (EIA) for the 
proposed improvements of harbors identified in the engineering study; conduct a 
field  survey  to  produce  a  comprehensive  environmental  assessment,  with 
emphasis on waste disposal areas, mangroves, coral reefs, and the estuary 
ecosystem, especially in light of the Maldives’ vulnerability to climate change 
impacts;  and  recommend  measures  to  prevent,  minimize,  mitigate,  or 
compensate  for  adverse  impacts  and  improve  environmental  performance, 
including their costs. 
(ii)  Prepare an initial environmental examination (IEE), including an environmental 
management  plan  (EMP),  and  its  summary  in  accordance  with  ADB's 
environmental  assessment  guidelines,  and  the  Government's  environmental 
policy and guideline. 
(iii)  If  the  IEE  recommends  undertaking  a  full  EIA,  prepare  terms  of  reference 
acceptable to ADB and the Government, conduct the EIA, and prepare the EIA 
report, including an EMP and its summary  in accordance with ADB's policies, 
procedures, and the EIA guidelines, 2003. 
 
B.  Required Expertise 
8.  The consultant team will comprise a transport planner and economist (maritime) as team 
leader, a maritime or coastal engineer, a financial analyst in transport, a social and resettlement 
specialist, and an environmental specialist (maritime) for a total of about 45 person-months (15 
international and 30 domestic consultant inputs). 
 
C.   Reports 
9.  The following reports will be submitted to the Government and ADB: 
 
(i)  Inception report. Submitted within 1 month of the start of consulting services, 
highlighting progress made, initial findings with candidate project elements, and 
any  recommendations  and  proposed  changes  to  the  work  program.  The 
inception report will include preliminary recommendations and justification of the 
project components based on existing studies such as the Transport Master Plan 
study. 
(ii)  Interim report. Submitted within 3 months of the start, including preliminary 
study results for the proposed project. Necessary inputs and assistance will be 
provided to help the ADB loan processing and fact-finding mission. 
(iii)  Draft Final Report. Submitted within 5 months of the start, including final study 
results for the project and reports on safeguard issues. 
(iv)  Final Report. Submitted within 1 month of receipt of comments on the draft final 
report, after due consideration of comments made by the Government and ADB. 
(v)  Progress reports. A brief progress report submitted at the end of each month to 
ADB and the Government by e-mail or fax, indicating the administrative and 
technical accomplishments achieved during the month. 
 
10.  Twenty copies (5 copies for ADB and 15 copies for the Government) of each document 
except progress reports will be submitted.
